title: Pittsfield man, 69, killed in hit-and-run crash that dragged him ‘lengthy distance,’ DA says
author: Carson Lyle
bullets: William Colbert, 69, was killed in a hit-and-run in Pittsfield, dragged a lengthy distance by a dark-colored sedan.
The incident occurred near Linden Street and Francis Avenue; the victim was found dead near West Housatonic Street.
The driver fled the scene and is being sought by police; authorities seek information from the public.

title: ‘This is only the beginning’: Ann Michael Maye shares encouraging message after Patriots Super Bowl loss
author: Khari A. Thompson
bullets: The Patriots lost Super Bowl LX to the Seahawks 29-13, despite a record quarter by QB Drake Maye.
Ann Michael Maye shared a positive message on Instagram, thanking supporters and expressing optimism for the future.
Drake Maye looks forward to the offseason with his wife, Ann Michael, amid her growing popularity for 'Bakemas' videos.

title: This dad is running Boston to give back to Boston Children’s Hospital
author: Autumn Sloboda
bullets: Nick Gallagher, 38, from Plymouth is running the 2026 Boston Marathon for Boston Children's Hospital's Miles for Miracles team.
Gallagher's participation honors the care his son received from the hospital's neurology team after his birth 4 years ago.
He aims to give back and motivate others to support families receiving life-changing treatments at Boston Children's Hospital.

title: Her great-grandfather ran the Boston Marathon in 1920. Now she’s doing the same.
author: Autumn Sloboda
bullets: Juliette Barney, 23, from Braintree is running the 2026 Boston Marathon to support the Youth Advocacy Foundation's mission.
Barney's great-grandfather ran the Boston Marathon in 1920, finishing 16th, inspiring her participation in the event.
The Youth Advocacy Foundation helps young people with legal support and educational advocacy, which Barney aims to raise funds for.

title: Should Boston rebuild Madison Park at Roxbury’s P-3 site?
author: Annie Jonas
bullets: The parcel P-3 site in Roxbury remains undeveloped after multiple failed projects, with the latest proposal facing economic challenges.
Mayor Wu's administration proposes relocating Madison Park Technical Vocational High School to the 7.7-acre site in Roxbury.
Development company HYM wishes to proceed with the original mixed-use plan despite economic concerns and shifting city priorities.

title: Tom Brady roasts Logan Paul, calls wrestler’s athletic abilities ‘cute’
author: Khari A. Thompson
bullets: Tom Brady and Logan Paul are set to compete in the Fanatics Flag Football Classic in Saudi Arabia next month.
Brady commented on Paul's athletic abilities during an appearance on Paul's podcast, saying they are "cute" compared to real athletes.
The flag football tournament will feature NFL stars like Saquon Barkley and Rob Gronkowski and will be broadcast live on Fox Sports.

title: Massachusetts emergency room wait times rank among the longest in the U.S.
author: Annie Jonas
bullets: Massachusetts ranks third in the U.S. for longest emergency room wait times, averaging 189 minutes.
Emergency room stays over 12 hours increased to 9.9% in Massachusetts by early 2024 from 6.6% in 2020.
Healthcare workforce vacancies, especially in mental health, contribute to lengthy ER wait times in Massachusetts.

title: Report: Retired 5x Pro Bowl left-tackle offers to help train Will Campbell
author: Khari A. Thompson
bullets: Terron Armstead offers to train Patriots' Will Campbell to improve his technique after a tough Super Bowl performance.
Campbell struggled with pressures and the offensive line's effectiveness was questioned, receiving feedback from retired players.
Armstead, a five-time Pro Bowler, believes Campbell's issues are fixable with offseason training in Dallas.

title: More than 400 readers voted: $240K in-office Boston job or $120K remote?
author: Autumn Sloboda
bullets: 56% chose a $240,000 in-person Boston job over a $120,000 remote position, according to a poll of over 400 readers.
Many prefer the remote option for flexibility, citing less commuting and better family balance, despite the lower salary.
Supporters of the higher salary argue the financial benefits and desire for office social interaction outweigh commute challenges.

title: City councilor calls for restrictions on e-bikes and mopeds, including ban for food delivery drivers
author: Ross Cristantiello
bullets: Boston Councilor Ed Flynn proposes restrictions on e-bikes and mopeds, citing public safety concerns and a rise in injuries.
Proposals include banning e-bikes over 20 mph from bike lanes and prohibiting third-party food delivery drivers from using them.
DoorDash opposes the ban, arguing it could increase car deliveries and negatively impact local businesses and workers.
